repos/list-releases.name: Improve error reporting for `EncodingError` and `DecodingError`
repos/list-releases.body:
###### _This patch was authored by @grahamburgsma and released by @0xTim._

As `EncodingError` and `DecodingError` both conform to `LocalizedError`, error reporting uses their `localizedDescription` which is just a generic error message.

So this changes the error reporting from:
> The operation could not be completed. The data isnâ€™t in the correct format.

To a description much more useful (for example):
> invalidValue(inf, Swift.EncodingError.Context(codingPath: [...], debugDescription: "Unable to encode Double.inf directly in JSON.", underlyingError: nil))

pulls/list-review-comments.body: `Swift.Error` already requires `Sendable` conformance. No need to the conformance again. This is applies to all custom error types in this PR.

Use `NIOLockedValueBox` instead of `storageLock` and separate `storage`. The compiler can then infere the `Sendable` conformance and you can drop `@unchecked`. This will also allow you to make this a struct instead of a class as `NIOLockedValueBox` is already a reference type. Document that the struct has reference semantics now.
`Sendable` should be automatically inferred for internal and lower visibility types. If not, please fill an issue.

I can't use `NIOLockedValueBox` though because of the use of `Any` right? I can't guarantee that anything being inserted into the storage is `Sendable` at which point `NIOLockedValueBox` is _not_ `Sendable`

Won't this introduce double-locking? Accessing `storage` will lock `main` and the lock contained in `NIOLockedValueBox`.
I'm not sure the `NIOLockedValueBox` is necessary here.

Changing this to a `struct` is theoretically semver-breaking:

```swift
func useClass<C: AnyObject>(_ c: C) {}

useClass(Application().locks) // now fails
```

Could be acceptable, though, since I don't see a reasonable use-case for such a function.

Feels a bit weird to have to close a lock to access locks. The only reason for this is `locks` being settable, right?. I know it's a breaking change to remove the setter, but it might be possible to mark it as `@available(*, noasync)`.
True, but given that `Cache` is anyways `@unchecked Sendable` due to `storage` not being `Sendable`, it wouldn't matter if the `NIOLockedValueBox` isn't `Sendable` either, right?
Shouldn't `Provider` become `Sendable`?

pulls/list-review-comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,19 +12,20 @@ extension Application {
 
     public struct Clients {
pulls/list-review-comments.body: `Clients` could become `Sendable`
Given that `AsyncResponseEncodable` requires `Sendable`, this requirement here is not needed.
This can be `Sendable` as well
`Swift.Error` already requires `Sendable`. So this wouldn't be necessary here.
`Middleware` already requires `Sendable`. So it wouldn't be necessary to add the requirement here as well.
`Middleware` already includes the `Sendable` requirement. `ErrorMiddleware` wouldn't need to declare it separately.

pulls/list-review-comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,14 +1,90 @@
 import NIOHTTP1
 import RoutingKit
+import NIOConcurrencyHelpers
 
-public final class Route: CustomStringConvertible {
-    public var method: HTTPMethod
-    public var path: [PathComponent]
-    public var responder: Responder
-    public var requestType: Any.Type
-    public var responseType: Any.Type
+// This needs to be unchecked because of the use of `Any` throughout which means we can't use
+// helpers like NIOLockedValueBox
pulls/list-review-comments.body: You could still use `NIOLockedValueBox`. `@unchecked Sendable` should allow non-Sendable members.
Could also become `Sendable`
`CodingKey` already requires `Sendable` - so it wouldn't need to be explicitly required here as well.
`ResponseEncodable` already includes the `Sendable` requirement. It could be left out here.
This could also use `NIOLockedValueBox`

Instead of requiring it, this could be made an extension:
```swift
extension RangeResult: Sendable where T: Sendable {}
```

Or is there a specific reason for `RangeResult` to require it?
`Swift.Error` already includes the `Sendable` requirement. It wouldn't need to be stated again here.
This could also become `Sendable.
This might become `Sendable` as well.
Other `Storage`s made the closure `@Sendable`. Was this forgotten here, or is it intentional?
`Swift.CodingKey` already includes the `Sendable` requirement. Not strictly necessary here again.
Could also become `Sendable` (potentially `@unchecked`), now that all values are protected by a lock.
`Client` already requires `Sendable`. Not strictly needed here again.
Could this be come `Sendable` as well with all the locks now?
